title: Christians should stop quoting the Bible in every debate saying "it's God's word", as if that settled it, since the Bible is just a compilation of books made by men to interpret God's will

author: Specialist-Square419
text:
This post seems hypocritical to me because we each have our worldview that we use to explain the world/our observations to our satisfaction. For the Christian, that worldview is that Scripture/Bible is the unquestionable authority that is presumed true. For the Muslims, it‚Äôs the Koran. For atheists, it‚Äôs naturalism.

So, we all do the same thing, using a different worldview. Why bash Christians for doing something you and everyone else does, too, OP?

author: [deleted]
text:
>Why bash Christians for doing something you and everyone else does, too, OP?

Because it's not based on reality or intellectual honesty. Trying to prove scripture is true by quoting scripture is downright clownish.

author: Specialist-Square419
text: That wasn‚Äôt what was being discussed. The topic was hypocritical standards. Christians do not bash the atheist‚Äôs reliance upon naturalism as their unequivocal explanatory authority, but atheists refuse to reciprocate.

author: Phage0070
text: It is a bit disturbing that you don't acknowledge reality as being a legitimately privileged authority.

author: Specialist-Square419
text: We both live and experience the same reality, but interpret that same reality‚Äîor, set of data‚Äîthrough two opposing lens, or worldviews.

author: DDD000GGG
text:
Right.

But the big important difference is that interpreting reality through a scientific lens provides an interpretation that is universally consistent.

Interpreting reality through the lens of religion requires dogma, magical thinking and mental gymnastics in order for it to remain even remotely "consistent".

Saying that "we're just looking at things from a different perspective" is a total cop out.

It's like believing that 2+2=5 and then you meet someone who can prove to you that 2+2=4, always has and always will, but you just say "we just see it differently, I guess".

It makes you look ridiculous.

author: Specialist-Square419
text: I‚Äôm not worried about how I look. Thanks for the engagement. Have a great day ;)

author: DDD000GGG
text: How did you arrive at the religion you believe in? Were you born and raised in it?

author: Specialist-Square419
text: No, I was not raised in a Christian home/family. I am a journalist/researcher by trade and, due to some childhood trauma, I was drawn to what Christianity teaches. So I launched an investigation and became convinced it was truth. How bout you?

author: DDD000GGG
text:
Yes, born and raised. Thankfully, I was pushed to question the dogma and doctrine enough to see that it is a construct and nothing more.

I am sorry to hear that you had to go through childhood trauma. Whatever it was, you didn't deserve it. No child does. It not uncommon for people to be drawn to religions under such circumstances.

I have some questions; what about Christianity specifically drew you to it? What is unique about Christianity from your perspective?

There is much that naturalism cannot explain; and one could argue that is because it automatically rules out the true explanation, which happens to be a supernatural one.

author: Purgii
text:
> statistical improbability of over 300 fulfilled prophesies and zero false prophesies.

It's simple for prophecy to be fulfilled when you're writing after your chosen subject had died and decades have passed. It also doesn't help when you mistranslate prophecy which invalidates your claimant.

The statistical improbability of guessing the result of 100 d20 rolls is enormous - unless you record the value after the die is rolled.

But for me, the most noticeable prophecies that haven't come to pass is the age of world peace and everyone knowing the one true god.

author: Specialist-Square419
text:
Your assertion is true, but I am satisfied by the authentication studies (that included hard skeptics and nonChristians) that such was/is not the case regarding the Bible. And I admit my bias/worldview that precludes any explanation that denies a Creator/God. But I do understand your unwillingness to accept such evidence, given YOUR worldview.

My point is that those who hold to naturalism or uniformitarianism‚Äîor any belief system that precludes potentially true explanations based on one‚Äôs BELIEF‚Äîis just as biased as mine.

author: Purgii
text:
You've misrepresented my position. I don't have a 'worldview' that denies a creator god, I just haven't been provided sufficient reason to believe that one exists. There's nothing about what I believe that excludes that possibility.

> but I am satisfied by the authentication studies (that included hard skeptics and nonChristians) that such was/is not the case regarding the Bible.

I don't understand what that means? If you rely on prophecy to vet a messiah claimant, there's no such thing as close enough. Wars have raged on since Jesus' death - neither of us agree about the one true god. We're not in the messianic age.

author: [deleted]
text:
Because arguments based on "naturalism", as you say, can be replied to, and sometimes it is proven that they were wrong or outdated. It allows reflection and changing your mind.

text:
>Because arguments based on "naturalism", as you say, can be replied to, and sometimes it is proven that they were wrong or outdated. It allows reflection and changing your mind.
